Description: Mould-made pottery oil-lamp with a heart-shaped nozzle, decorated on the discus with the relief of a dog (Sothis). The shoulder is decorated with three incised rings surrounding. At the rear is an Egyptian ring handle. The oil-lamp stands on a raised base, with three incised rings. Brown (Nile silt?) fabric with black surfaces, possibly a slip or from over-firing.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels in the British Museum include ovule patterning and animal subjects on earlier 75AD to 200AD handle-less lamps (Bailey 1988, British Museum Lamps III, Q2014, to Q2017). Parallels of this form from Mons Claudianus were found in deposits dated to the Antonine period of the 2nd century AD (Knowles 2006, Type, nos 135-141). Roman Ehnasya parallel (Petrie1905, 5, pl. 53) cited on Philadelphia register card. Possibly imported fabric. Knowles, K. 2006. The pottery lamps. In V.A.Maxfield and D.P.S. Peacock, Survey and excavation at Mons Claudianus 1987-1993. Vol.3 Ceramic vessels and related objects. IFAO Cairo. 309–426. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905. Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904. London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KE.30) (Phase 3)
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4838 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
